body: Can you try the MyGet build?
Just tested, I can confirm that `5.1.0-alpha-01176` still has the issue.
Yes, it's a bug. ConvertUsing is the method to use for Map, ProjectUsing is for LINQ.

Yep, and at one point ProjectUsing set ConvertUsing

> is for LINQ.

Ok, I'll change it to `ConvertUsing`. But just to clarify again: The bug exists with `ConvertUsing`, too.
:) Yes, that's more for future reference. The fix is easy enough, but we should merge another PR first.

issue.title: Convert using to string
issue.body:
fixes #1529
use ResolveTypeMap instead of GetTypeMap
special case CreateMissingTypeMaps to avoid the overhead on the normal path

body: BTW, is it possible to disable the `ToString()` handling entirely? I don't use it at all, so I would prefer if AutoMapper reported a missing mapping from `T` to `string` instead of assuming that I want to call `T.ToString()`.

Yes, when you create the mapper configuration from a list of object
mappers, just remove the StringMapper from the list in MapperRegistry.

On Tuesday, July 19, 2016, Dani Michel notifications@github.com wrote:

> BTW, is it possible to disable the ToString() handling entirely? I don't
> use it at all, so I would prefer if AutoMapper reported a missing mapping
> from T to string instead of assuming that I want to call T.ToString().
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you modified the open/close state.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/1529#issuecomment-233554293,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAGYMiL02BzsF6l9R8ZYpLonQT3px-BFks5qXH5jgaJpZM4JNNOo
> .
@jbogard I thought so too, but no :) That ToString is hard-coded now, I'm not sure the StringMapper does much anymore.

Following the [principle of least surprise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment) I would even suggest to make the string mapping opt-in (in a future release). But that's a breaking change, and you probably had enough breaking changes just now :-)

Yeah that's been a feature since probably the first couple of months. And
tbqh you're the first person that's been surprised about automatic string
mapping in the 8 or so years AutoMapper has been around. If I took away the
string mapping, I'd need to take away the close to 100 other automatic type
conversions that AutoMapper has that it uses based on built-in type
conversions already in .NET.

What I think we _could_ (and probably need to do) is catalog the built-in
mappings and conversions. That's not really documented explicitly anywhere.

On Tue, Jul 19, 2016 at 8:03 AM, Dani Michel notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Following the principle of least surprise
> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment I would
> even suggest to make the string mapping opt-in in a future release. But
> that's a breaking change, and you probably had enough breaking changes just
> now :-)
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/1529#issuecomment-233625325,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAGYMtmj5y-2nP86A63xG4-CWY3d6nUcks5qXMsEgaJpZM4JNNOo
> .
Well, opt-out would be nice :) But until someone is bothered enough...
I'm easily surprised :-D . That would be perfectly fine for me, a list of the automatic mappings, and a guideline about how to disable some of them.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
